headline: Production support team :- software engineer L3 Pune
pros: I don't think there are any pros in working for PayU .. expect its lil bit known brand
cons:
1 ) I worked in payu around one and half year . To be quite honest first 12 months went smoothly under our team lead .but he moved to another team and then came the current lead.. under qualified,egoistic,inexperienced person.

2) due to the current management pressure,mental harasment and inability to handle the team there were around 13 resignations from this team in last 9 to 10 months.Its hard to survive there for more than 6 months

3) This is a product base company they have 50+ product that needs to handle by support team and need atleast a year to understand properly. But current lead will want u to ready in just 10 days.(it took us year to get stable without any pressure.)

4) Currently there is so much pressure on this team that you are forced to work 11 hours a day. Please note that u won't be paid for extra hours as this is not official. U have to work on Saturday and Sunday even though you will have officially offday.. here as well u won't be paid anything extra. When you are asked to work extra for everyday ask them to send an official mail for this request.

5) HR team knows everything,  but they don't want to do anything about it.. they know there are more resignations in this team in last 10 months than last 5 years.  They simply don't want to help here.If you think you will reach out to the higher management.. it won't help as well... These people working here for year's and friends.. You think you are telling them in confidence but in reality it will be spread to everyone in their group in hours .

6) if you think this is a MNC and will have certain standards ,I am here to tell you it's not... After reading this you are still accepting the offer from payu in this team ,then you must need this job. U will have some money at the end but no mental stability.

headline: Management Layer is worst. No one listen you. They just Pretend to listen you but do nothing
pros:
1. Flexible working hours
2. Lots of learning
cons:
1. Management Layer treat you like a slave. Whatever good thing you do, they will never value you.
2. There is no mean of giving feedback to upper management if you are facing any issue. Then will not take any action.
3. Some people (At managerial level) who are working from long time behave like a Boss. They treat you as slave and give you lecture on policies however there is no policy like that in the company. They want you to work for more than 11 hours and even after doing that, they have no value for you.
4. People usually prefer late hour meeting. This should be avoided. They say that they have flexible working policy but in real you get lots of meeting in off office hours so no flexibility for you who want to spend personal hours with family.
5. They have come up with a policy "No call / meeting on Wednesday" but in reality you do have lots of meeting on Wednesday.
6. Sales team drive the engineering. You have to build the product in hurry. The want each and every product in a day. No priorities given to quality of code and good design.
7. HR is there to just arrange Friday fun activity. They are not there to help you as an employee if you are having any problem with your manager.
8. There are manager / Senior who are not following good coding practices. If you ask them to follow then they say we just need to solve the problem. keep aside good practices.
9. No software Engineering principle follow here while developing application. This is why they come up with a longer roadmap to redesign every thing. But in the end it will be a mess if we do not follow good practices.
10. There is a technical design review meeting happens every week. You get feedback and pointers to think of in that meeting. But your team manager ask you to ignore the feedback and force you to write the bad code.

headline: Associate Product Manager
pros:
-A lot of freedom in terms of what you can do, there is no one stopping you from what you want to do as long as you are ready to put up a good fight to get it implemented.

-PayU India is only a 550 people company but is part of Naspers Group so it has a Half startup -Half MNC work culture, which means whatever you do have an impact and also you will be able to maintain a decent work-life balance.

-Free lunch, good opportunities to travel within India.

-International Offsites and a good party filled work culture. 

- Complete freedom to work from anywhere. You are measured based on your performance and not based on obsolete parameters like work hours.

-Depending on your product/team, you will also get opportunities to work and interact with PayU Global team, which will also open up some good work and travel opportunities.
cons:
Most of the engineering team for core Payments business is based out of Gurgaon, so working with your team from anywhere other than Gurgaon is extremely difficult.

The work culture is a mix of old and new, good and bad. While some teams are extremely agile, open and have some of the brightest minds in the country, a few teams lag behind which affects the overall go to market time for most products.

In general, most people you come across are extremely hardworking, so there is a general expectation to get a reply to incoming emails and a calls even when you are on leave / after office hours/ weekends, though people in general respect your choice to detach yourself from work during your personal time.
